entries.name: Artificer: Variant Capstones
entries: The Soul of Artifice feature an Artificer gains at 20th level allows them to cheat death—sacrificing their creations to regain Hit Points when they drop to 0 Hit Points—and to regain uses of Flash of Genius after completing a Short Rest. While these are useful, they are also passive abilities that don't capture the flavor of a particular subclass. With the DM's permission, an Artificer who reaches level 20 can choose an alternative feature associated with their subclass instead of Soul of Artifice. This section presents variant capstones for the two subclasses introduced in this book, as well as the Alchemist, Armorer, Artillerist, Battle Smith, and Cartographer.

entries.name: Alchemist - Level 20: Perfected Elixirs
entries: You can create perfect elixirs with potent effects. When you produce elixirs at the end of a Long Rest, you also create one Panacea elixir and one Vivacity elixir. These elixirs follow the same rules as your other elixirs, but they can't be produced in any other way.

items.name: Panacea
items.entry: The drinker is restored to full Hit Points and all conditions affecting them are ended. If the drinker has died within the last hour, they instead revive with 1 Hit Point. This elixir can't revive a creature that has died of old age, nor does it restore any missing body parts.

items.name: Vivacity
items.entry: The drinker gains the benefits of your Resilience, Boldness, and Flight elixirs for 8 hours. When gained in this way, the Flight elixir grants a Fly Speed of 50 feet.

entries.name: Armorer - Level 20: Overcharge
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can overcharge your armor to unleash a torrent of energy forming a 100-foot-long, 15-foot-wide {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} that blasts out from you in a direction you choose. The type of energy unleashed by the Line depends on your current armor model: Dreadnaught deals Force damage, Guardian deals Thunder damage, and Infiltrator deals Lightning damage. Each creature in the Line makes a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 30d6} damage of the appropriate type on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Artillerist - Level 20: Infused Cannon
entries: You can infuse your cannons with eldritch energy, empowering them to produce more powerful effects. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can cause one or both of your cannons to produce one of the effects listed below. Multiple cannons can use the same option or different ones.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Long Rest. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 5 spell slot (no action required).

items.name: Dragonflame
items.entry: The cannon exhales fire in a 60-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. Each creature in that area makes a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 5d8} Fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Flammable objects in the Cone that aren't being worn or carried start burning.

items.name: Barrage
items.entry: The cannon lobs a ball of concentrated energy at a point you choose within 120 feet of it. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on that point makes a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 5d8} Force damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. A nonmagical object that isn't being worn or carried also takes the damage if it's in the target area, and this damage ignores the damage threshold of objects.

items.name: Restoration
items.entry: The cannon emits a wave of curative energy, targeting itself and each creature of your choice within 10 feet of it. Each target regains 25 Hit Points and is cured of the Blind, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, and {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} conditions.

entries.name: Battle Smith - Level 20: Steel Vanguard
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action with {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB} in hand, you infuse your Steel Defender with arcane energy, granting it the following benefits for 1 minute.

items.name: Multiattack
items.entry: The Steel Defender gains the Multiattack action, allowing it to make four Force-Empowered Rend attacks.

items.name: Flight
items.entry: The Steel Defender gains a Fly Speed equal to its Speed.

items.name: Protective Shield
items.entry: The Steel Defender gains 50 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

items.name: Limitless Jolt
items.entry: Using Arcane Jolt does not expend uses.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you expend a level 5 spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Cartographer - Level 20: Travel Anywhere
entries: If you are one of the map holders for your Adventurer's Atlas, you can cast {@spell Gate|XPHB} without a Material component. You can also cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in this way when you finish a Long Rest.

When you cast the spell with this feature, the duration extends to 10 minutes and damage can't cause you to lose {@status Concentration|XPHB}. Also, you can choose to link the portal to a precise location on the same plane of existence or a different plane of existence.

entries.name: Forge Adept - Level 20: Weapon of Legend
entries: You are able to connect your spirit to your allies, making them living weapons. You gain the following benefits while wielding your Ghaal'Shaarat.

items.name: Constant Aura
items.entry: Your Aura of War is always active, and you can take a Bonus Action to change its damage type.

items.name: Retributive Aura
items.entry: Whenever an enemy starts its turn in your Aura of War, that creature takes damage equal to the extra damage provided by the aura.

items.name: Empower Aura
items.entry: As a Bonus Action, you can increase the extra damage provided by your Aura of War to {@dice 2d6}. This increase lasts for 1 minute. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Maverick - Level 20: Improved Genius
entries: You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to cast any spell of level 8 or lower. This takes the place of the usual casting time of the spell, and you don't need to meet any requirements to cast the spell, including costly components; the spell simply takes effect. Once you cast a spell with this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Artificer: Forge Adept
entries: {@i Craft a Mighty Weapon out of Your Soul}

The daashor artificers of the Dhakaani Empire were the finest weaponsmiths in Khorvaire's history, as discussed in {@book Uncharted Domains|ExploringEberron24|4}. As a Forge Adept, you carry on these ancient traditions, creating mystical weapons and armor, strengthening allies on the battlefield, and bringing down enemies with weapons imbued with your own soul energy. If you're dar, you learned these techniques from the masters of your clan. Are you content to follow ancient traditions, or do you want to add your own innovations? If you're not Dhakaani, did you learn these techniques from a daashor mentor? Did you steal this knowledge? Or are you replicating these traditions on your own?

entries.name: Level 3: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB}. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of Artisan's Tools of your choice.
In addition, when you craft an ordinary or magic weapon, the amount of time required to craft it is halved.

entries.name: Level 3: Forge Adept Spells
entries: When you reach an Artificer level specified in the Forge Adept Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Forge Adept Spells
rows: {@spell Armor of Agathys|XPHB}, {@spell Shield of Faith|XPHB}
{@spell Spiritual Weapon|XPHB}, {@spell Warding Bond|XPHB}
{@spell Beacon of Hope|XPHB}, {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB}
{@spell Death Ward|XPHB}, {@spell Fire Shield|XPHB}
{@spell Banishing Smite|XPHB}, {@spell Wall of Force|XPHB}

entries.name: Level 3: Battle Ready
entries: Your combat training and your experiments with magic have paid off in two ways:

items.name: Arcane Empowerment
items.entry: When you attack with a magic weapon, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls.

items.name: Weapon Knowledge
items.entry: You gain proficiency with Martial weapons. You can use a weapon with which you have proficiency as a Spellcasting Focus for your Artificer spells.

entries.name: Level 3: Ghaal'Shaarat
entries: You can imbue a weapon with a fraction of your spirit, creating what the Dhakaani daashors call a ghaal'shaarat, Goblin for "mighty blade." As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action while you have {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB} in hand, you can turn a Simple or Martial Melee weapon into a Ghaal'Shaarat. The weapon continues to be a Ghaal'Shaarat until you imbue a different weapon or you die.
The weapon gains the following benefits while you wield it.

items.name: Mighty Blade
items.entry: A nonmagical weapon becomes a magic weapon. You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the weapon, unless it already had this bonus or a better one.

items.name: Returning Weapon
items.entry: The weapon has the Thrown property with a normal range of 30 feet and a long range of 120 feet. It returns to your hand immediately after it is used to make a ranged attack roll.

entries.name: Level 5: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice instead of once whenever you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn.

entries.name: Level 9: Runes of War
entries: You gain the following benefits while wielding your Ghaal'Shaarat.

items.name: Improved Mighty Blade
items.entry: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the weapon, unless it already had this bonus or a better one.

items.name: Aura of War
items.entry: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you begin radiating a bolstering aura in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} that originates from you. Choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder. While in the aura, you and your allies each deal an extra {@dice 1d4} damage of the chosen type when hitting with a weapon attack or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}. The aura lasts for 1 minute, until you use this feature again, or until you end it (no action required). You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Level 15: Perfect Weapon
entries: The connection of your spirit to your weapon has been perfected. You gain the following benefits while wielding your Ghaal'Shaarat.

items.name: Perfect Mighty Blade
items.entry: You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the weapon, unless it already had this bonus or a better one. Additionally, the first time you attack with your Ghaal'Shaarat on your turn, you can transfer some or all of the weapon's bonus to your Armor Class. The bonus remains until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Elemental Strike
items.entry: When you hit a creature with an attack roll using your Ghaal'Shaarat, choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder. Your Ghaal'Shaarat deals an extra {@dice 1d6} damage of the chosen type; and you can cause the weapon to deal the chosen type of damage or its normal damage type.

items.name: Soul Bound
items.entry: You have Resistance to Psychic damage, and you have Immunity to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions.

entries.name: Artificer: Maverick
entries: {@i Craft the Tool You Need in the Moment}

A Maverick Artificer is always tinkering, forever chasing a new idea. Where other Artificers focus on a single path of arcane science, the strength of the Maverick is flexibility. They may lack the discipline or credentials of their scholarly colleagues, but Mavericks have a talent for cobbling together exactly what's needed to solve any problem.

entries.name: Level 3: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}. If you already have proficiency with Tinker's Tools, you gain proficiency with one other type of Artisan's Tools of your choice.
In addition, when you craft a magic item, the amount of time required to craft it is halved.

entries.name: Level 3: Maverick Spells
entries: You learn one cantrip of your choice from the Artificer, Cleric, or Wizard spell list. The chosen cantrip counts as an Artificer spell for you, and Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for it.

In addition, any time you prepare Artificer spells, you can prepare an additional number of spells equal to your Proficiency Bonus. These additional spells can be chosen from the Artificer, Cleric, and Wizard spells lists, and the chosen spells count as Artificer spells for you.

entries.name: Level 3: Arcane Prototype
entries: You're always working on new projects, crafting Arcane Prototypes. You determine a prototype's appearance, but its functionality is always similar to that of a Spell Scroll—it holds the effect of a spell that can be unleashed at a later time. Only you can use a prototype to cast a spell; they're experimental creations that no one else can truly understand.

Your ability to constantly come up with new ideas is represented by Arcane Charges. You have 1 Arcane Charge, and you gain more as you reach higher levels, as shown in the Arcane Charges level of the Arcane Prototypes table. You can't have more Arcane Charges than the number shown in the table for your level. You regain all expended Arcane Charges when you finish a Long Rest.

You can use your Arcane Charges to imbue spells into your prototypes, up to the level shown in the Max Spell Level of the Arcane Prototypes table. While a prototype is in your possession, you can cast the imbued spell without expending a spell slot, without preparing the spell, and without Material components. Casting the spell in this way requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the prototype crumbles to dust, unless you choose to preserve it by expending a spell slot equal to the level of the spell.

{@b Imbuing Spells into your Prototypes}. When you finish a Long Rest, you can create a prototype if you have {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} in hand. When you reach certain Artificer levels specified in the Artificer Level column of the Arcane Prototypes table, the number of prototypes you can create at the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} increases.

When you create a prototype, choose a spell from the Artificer, Cleric, or Wizard spell list. This expends a number of Arcane Charges equal to the level of the spell, up to the maximum spell level allowed. For example, if you're a level 9 Artificer, you can create up to 3 prototypes, each with a maximum spell level of 3, expending a total of 5 Arcane Charges to do so; you could create two level 1 prototypes and one level 3 prototype; one level 2 prototype and one level 3 prototype, or one level 1 prototype and two level 2 prototypes.

entries.name: Level 5: Fine Tuning
entries: Whenever you cast an Artificer spell while you have {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} in your possession, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of the spell.

entries.name: Level 9: Work in Progress
entries: Whenever you finish a Short Rest, you can replace one of your prepared spells with a new spell from the Artificer, Cleric, or Wizard spell list. This spell counts as an Artificer spell for you.

entries.name: Level 15: Final Breakthrough
entries: Whenever you finish a Short Rest, you can swap a spell contained in your Prototype for another spell of the same level, chosen from the Artificer, Cleric, or Wizard spell list.
In addition, you ignore all class, species, spell, and level requirements on attuning to or using a magic item.

entries.name: Bard: College of the Dirge Singer
entries: {@i Bolster your Allies with Story and Song}

Students of both history and war, Dirge Singer Bards use tales of past glory to inspire their allies and provide keen strategic insight, directing their comrades to strike when enemies are weak. This college was born in the Empire of Dhakaan, but over the course of the Last War, Cyre developed its own version of these techniques, and now Bards that follow this path keep the memory of their fallen nation alive through song.

entries.name: Level 3: Broad Inspiration
entries: You know how to strengthen the hearts of your troops and stir them to greatness. You learn the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip, which counts as a Bard spell for you. The cantrip doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.
Additionally, when you confer a Bardic Inspiration die to a creature, you can also confer that Bardic Inspiration die to a second creature within range.

entries.name: Level 3: Keeper of History
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill History|XPHB} and {@skill Performance|XPHB} skills. If you already have these proficiencies, you instead gain Expertise.

entries.name: Level 6: Commanding Voice
entries: You excel at inspiring and directing soldiers in battle. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action or the {@action Magic|XPHB} action on your turn, two creatures of your choice who possess one of your Bardic Inspiration die can expend it to use their Reaction to immediately make one attack with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, adding the Bardic Inspiration die to the attack's damage roll on a hit.

entries.name: Level 14: Battle Hymn
entries: You unflaggingly maintain the spirits and discipline of your unit. As a Bonus Action, you can start a Battle Hymn which can be heard by all creatures within 60 feet. The hymn lasts until the start of your next turn. While the hymn is active, whenever an ally within 30 feet who can hear you makes an ability check or a saving throw, they can add {@dice 1d4} to the ability check or save.

entries.name: Cleric: Mind Domain
entries: {@i Channel Divine Devotion into Psychic Power}

The Mind Domain celebrates the power of the mortal mind, channeling psychic energy to protect the faithful and smite your enemies. While this is most often associated with the Path of Light or the Riedran Path of Inspiration, followers of the daelkyr can also master this power. Visions of Xoriat can drive a priest to madness, but they can also reveal deadly secrets of the mind.

entries.name: Level 3: Mind Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Mind Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Mind Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Command|XPHB}, {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers|XPHB}, {@spell Mind Spike|XPHB}
{@spell Clairvoyance|XPHB}, {@spell Fear|XPHB}
{@spell Confusion|XPHB}, {@spell Phantasmal Killer|XPHB}
{@spell Synaptic Static|XPHB}, {@spell Telekinesis|XPHB}

entries.name: Level 3: Psychic Feedback
entries: When a creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself succeeds on a Wisdom saving throw, you can take a Reaction and expend a use of your Channel Divinity to impose Disadvantage on the saving throw, prying into their mind before they succeed or fail.

entries.name: Level 3: Psychic Force
entries: You learn to buffet your foes with mental power. When you cast a Cleric spell that deals Radiant damage, you can choose to have it inflict Psychic damage instead. When you cast a spell that deals Psychic damage, you can add your Charisma modifier to that spell's damage against one of the spell's targets.

entries.name: Level 6: Gestalt Anchor
entries: Your mental power increases, allowing you to project a sense of calm in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} that originates from you. The projection is inactive if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition.
You and your allies in the projection gain a +2 bonus to Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.
If another Mind Domain Cleric is present, a creature can only benefit from one Gestalt Anchor at a time.

entries.name: Level 17: Bend Reality
entries: When an ally you can see within 30 feet of yourself fails a saving throw, you can replace the roll with a 20, potentially changing the outcome. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: Druid: Circle of the Forged
entries: {@i Shape-shift into Beasts of Steel and Wood}

What is truly natural? The warforged are living creatures, despite being constructed from wood and steel. Druids who embrace the Circle of the Forged explore the potential of the warforged form, blending animal shapes with warforged durability. Only a handful of Druids follow this Circle. Did you learn these techniques from a mentor? Are you driven by instinct, still learning what you're capable of? Or, if you're a Warforged, were you designed with the potential to assume multiple forms... and if so, who created you, and why?

entries.name: Level 3: Skin of Steel
entries: You can channel the power of the forge when you assume a Wild Shape form, granting you the benefits below.

items.name: Challenge Rating
items.entry: The maximum Challenge Rating for the form equals your Druid level divided by 3 (round down).

items.name: Armor Class
items.entry: Until you leave the form, your AC equals 15 plus your Wisdom modifier if that total is higher than the Beast's AC.

items.name: Construct Resilience
items.entry: You have Resistance to Poison damage. You also have Advantage on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

items.name: Tireless
items.entry: You don't gain Exhaustion levels from dehydration, malnutrition, or suffocation. In addition, you don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep.

items.name: Obvious
items.entry: While in a Wild Shape form, your body is made from the same materials as a warforged; your muscles are rootlike tendrils, and they're protected by armored plates. It's obvious to an observer that you are not a normal animal.

entries.name: Level 3: Circle of the Forged Spells
entries: When you reach a Druid level specified in the Circle of the Forged Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Circle of the Forged Spells
rows: {@spell Blade Ward|XPHB}, {@spell Identify|XPHB}, {@spell Mirror Image|XPHB}
{@spell Haste|XPHB}
{@spell Fire Shield|XPHB}
{@spell Animate Objects|XPHB}

entries.name: Level 6: Elementally Imbued
entries: While in a Wild Shape form, you gain the following benefits.

items.name: Elemental Strikes
items.entry: Each of your attacks in a Wild Shape form can deal its normal damage type, Acid damage, Cold damage, Fire damage, or Lightning damage. You make this choice each time you hit with those attacks.

items.name: Elemental Cascade
items.entry: Choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, or Lightning. Once per turn when you hit with a Wild Shape form's attack, you can expend a spell slot (no action required) to deal extra damage of the chosen type equal to {@dice 1d6} per level of the spell slot, to a maximum of {@dice 5d6}. The target must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target suffers an effect based on the chosen damage type for 1 minute. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: Acid
items.entry: The target suffers a penalty to AC equal to half your Wisdom modifier (minimum 1).

items.name: Cold
items.entry: The target's Speed is 0 and they have Disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks.

items.name: Fire
items.entry: At the start of each of its turns, the target takes Fire damage equal to your Wisdom modifier.

items.name: Lightning
items.entry: The target can't make Opportunity Attacks, and the first attack it makes on each of its turns has Disadvantage.

entries.name: Level 10: Adamantine Hide
entries: While in a Wild Shape form, you gain Resistance to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.
In addition, when you are hit by an attack roll or forced to make a saving throw, you can take a Reaction and expend a use of Wild Shape to shape-shift into one of your Wild Shape forms.

entries.name: Level 14: Construction Perfection
entries: While in a Wild Shape form, you gain the following additional benefits.

items.name: Armor Class
items.entry: Until you leave the form, your AC equals 16 plus your Wisdom modifier if that total is higher than the Beast's AC.

items.name: Iron Mind
items.entry: You have Immunity to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, {@condition Petrified|XPHB}, and {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} conditions, and Poison damage.

entries.name: Monk: Warrior of the Living Weapon
entries: {@i Reshape Your Body for Battle}

Warriors of the Living Weapon pursue physical perfection, honing their body as a smith sharpens a sword. Their traditions are drawn from cultures of shape-shifters and creatures who fight with tooth and claw.

entries.name: Level 3: Martial Form
entries: At the start of your turn, you can expend 1 Focus Point to manifest your martial form. The form lasts for 10 minutes, until you use this feature again, or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. Choose one of the following options when you adopt the form.

items.name: Forged Heart
items.entry: Whenever you hit an object with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, the hit is a Critical Hit. In addition, whenever you hit a creature with an Unarmed Strike granted by Flurry of Blows, the target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet directly away from you.

items.name: Nightmare Shroud
items.entry: When you use Deflect Attacks, the attacking creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Traveler's Blade
items.entry: Your reach increases by 10 feet.

items.name: Weretouched
items.entry: When you reduce an enemy within 5 feet of you to 0 Hit Points, you gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die plus your Monk Level.

entries.name: Level 3: Mutable Strike
entries: You have the power to alter your natural weapons, growing claws or reinforcing your fists. Whenever you deal damage with your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, it can deal your choice of Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage.

entries.name: Level 6: Manifest blow
entries: You gain one of the following options of your choice.

items.name: Forged Heart
items.entry: Once per turn when you hit a creature with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you can deal extra damage of the same type equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die.

items.name: Nightmare Shroud
items.entry: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can expend 2 Focus Points to cause psychic energy to erupt from you. When you do so, each creature of your choice in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes Psychic damage equal to three rolls of your Martial Arts die, and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage.

items.name: Traveler's Blade
items.entry: Once per turn when you hit a creature with an Unarmed Strike, you can use both the Damage and the Grapple option. You are always considered to have a free hand when determining whether you can Grapple another creature.

items.name: Weretouched
items.entry: When you hit the same creature twice on your turn with Unarmed Strike you can expend up to 3 Focus Points to deal extra damage on your second hit. The damage equals a number of rolls of your Martial Arts die equal to the Focus Points expended, and is the same type as your triggering Unarmed Strike.

entries.name: Level 11: Reflexive Adaptation
entries: When you use Self-Restoration, the following conditions are added to the list of conditions you can remove: {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, and {@condition Grappled|XPHB}.

In addition, when you finish a {@variantrule Shoret Rest|XPHB} you can remove 1 level of Exhaustion from yourself and when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} you can remove all levels of Exhaustion from yourself.

entries.name: Level 17: Perfect Form
entries: Whenever you assume your Martial Form, you can expend an additional 3 Focus Points to gain the following benefits for as long as you remain in the form.

items.name: Mercurial Strikes
items.entry: Whenever you attack with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} granted by Flurry of Blows, you have Advantage.

items.name: Regeneration
items.entry: At the start of your turn, roll one Martial Arts die. You regain that many Hit Points.

items.name: Unbreakable Body
items.entry: You gain a +2 bonus to your Armor Class.

entries.name: Playing a Warrior of the Living Weapon
entries: The Warrior of the Living Weapon showcases techniques developed by different cultures and species. The {@b Forged Heart} is a recent path, developed by warforged exploring the potential of their constructed frames. This involves both the physical evolution of the body and harnessing the strength of steel and stone. The {@b Nightmare Shroud} is a kalashtar tradition. Rather than physically transforming, a nightmare Monk generates ectoplasmic projections, manifesting claws of shadow. Blending physical blows with psychic attacks, they strike fear into the minds of their enemies. A kalashtar typically surrounds themselves with the image of their quori spirit, but the shroud can take any shape. The {@b Traveler's Blade} was developed by tribal changelings, equipping the practitioners with versatile weapons that can't be taken away. A practitioner can grow bone blades or knuckle ridges, or stretch their limbs to strike a distant foe. The {@b Weretouched} techniques were developed by shifter champions of Olarune, honing the natural weapons and strengths innate to their species.

As a Warrior of the Living Weapon, you may draw on a singular technique, or you may instead combine multiple different styles. Both the abilities you gain from this subclass and the base abilities of the Monk class can reflect your ability to control and alter your physical form. When you use Slow Fall, you might be shifting your shape to craft gliding membranes (Traveler's Blade) or catching the air in an ectoplasmic cloak (Nightmare Shroud). Your Unarmored Defense reflects defensive shape-shifting, and when you develop Empowered Strikes it reflects an enhancement of your natural weapons.

Most of the Living Weapon techniques make use of natural gifts; for example, the Traveler's Blade assumes that you possess the malleable form of a Changeling. However, any member of any species can follow these paths. If you don't possess any innate shape-shifting gifts or a bond to a quori spirit, it's up to you and your DM to explain how you manifest these gifts. If you're not a Kalashtar, your Nightmare Shroud could be the ghost of an ancestor or lover, clinging to you and helping you fight. If you're not a Changeling, perhaps you were altered by the daelkyr or part of a Vadalis supersoldier program—you can't change your face, but you can still grow bone blades and stretch your limbs to strike distant foes.

entries.name: Backgrounds
entries: This section provides background options for Changelings, Dhakaani goblinoids, and Malenti, reflecting the unique heritage of these species.

entries.name: Changeling Traveler

items.name: Ability Scores:
items.entry: Dexterity, Wisdom, Charisma

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@area Focused Personas|41d|x}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception|XPHB} and {@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) 2 {@item Dagger|XPHB|Daggers}, {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Bedroll|XPHB}, 2 {@item Pouch|XPHB|Pouches}, {@item Shiftweave|ERLW} clothing, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You're an urban nomad wandering from city to city. You spent your childhood traveling with your family, using your abilities to evade your enemies. Do you strive to be a force for positive change in the world, or are you an opportunist looking out for yourself? Most Changeling Travelers are Changelings. If you're not a Changeling, you were born to a changeling parent and traveled with them; you could use a {@item Disguise Kit|XPHB} or illusion magic to mimic their abilities.

entries.name: Dhakaani Goblinoids
entries: Dhakaani characters have generally been raised in Kech vaults, and a Dhakaani character's background reflects their role in the Kech. Actual criminals are quite rare in the tightly controlled systems of the Vaults, but {@background Criminal|XPHB}, {@background Charlatan|XPHB}, or {@background Wayfarer|XPHB} could all be used to reflect the training of spies or Khesh'dar. {@background Sage|XPHB} or {@background Entertainer|XPHB} are both good options for a Duur'kala character, even though these Bards are more than mere entertainers. Regardless of the background you choose, this chapter presents a few alternative Origin feats intended for Dhakaani characters. The {@area Uul Dhakaan|41f|x} feat is available to all Dhakaani characters, while the {@area Khesh'dar Training|41c|x} feat is intended for members of the Silent Folk. With your DM's permission, you can substitute one of these Origin feats for the feat usually granted by your background.

entries.name: Malenti

items.name: Ability Scores:
items.entry: Dexterity, Intelligence, Charisma

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@area Aquatic Adaptation|41a|x}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception|XPHB} and {@skill Insight|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: Choose {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}, or {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) The equipment of a background related to the person you consumed; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You were born a sahuagin in the Eternal Dominion of the Thunder Sea, but ritual magic and the blood of the kar'lassa allowed you to consume and replace a surface dweller. You can never regain your original form; for all intents and purposes, you are who you appear to be. You're physically indistinguishable from them, and you have enough of their memories to fool even their family and friends. But you have the mind of a sahuagin, and you're loyal to the Dominion.

As a Malenti, the first question is why the Dominion chose to replace this particular person, and how your mission relates to your activities as an adventurer. It's possible that your only mission is to observe the dryskins and occasionally provide information to a sahuagin spymaster, or you might have a specific goal that drives your actions during your adventures.

entries.name: Species
entries: Heroes can emerge from any corner of the world. This section provides species and lineages that reflect many unique cultures of Eberron: {@area Aasimar|404|x} tied to Eberron's planes and religions; the dar of the {@area Kech Dhakaan|407|x}; the Gnolls of the Znir Pact; the half-orc Jhorguntaal; and the Ruinbound that have recently appeared in the Mror Holds. If your DM allows it, you can play one of these species.

entries.name: Aasimar
entries: These rare humanoids have no culture of their own. Rather, aasimar are individuals shaped by exposure to divine forces or the energies of the planes, as discussed in {@book Faiths of Eberron|ExploringEberron24|3}. The following variants reflect two unusual forms of Aasimar that can be found in Eberron: the {@area Fernian Aasimar|405|x}, infused with otherworldly fire, and the {@area Mabaran Aasimar|406|x}, bound to shadows and despair.

entries.name: Dhakaani Ghaal'dar (Hobgoblin)
entries: {@race Dhakaani Ghaal'dar (Hobgoblin)|ExploringEberron24|Dhakaani hobgoblins} are known as ghaal'dar, "mighty folk"—not to be confused with the Ghaal'dar tribes that dominate Darguun. The ghaal'dar are soldiers, scholars, and leaders, valued for their versatility and their vision.

entries.name: Dhakanni Golin'dar (Goblin)
entries: {@race Dhakanni Golin'dar (Goblin)|ExploringEberron24|Dhakaani goblins} are known as golin'dar, "quick folk." They reproduce and mature faster than other dar, and form the bulk of the labor force in Dhakaani society. This includes menial labor, agriculture, food preparation, and skilled craftwork. Though {@area ghaal'dar|407|x} are the primary smiths of weapons and armor, most other manufacturing is done by the golin'dar. While this work may be less dramatic than the martial paths of the ghaal'dar and {@area guul'dar|40b|x}, it's vital to survival and the golin'dar are respected for their contributions. Other golin'dar take a different path, that of the Khesh'dar, the Silent Folk who live in the shadows of the empire.

entries.name: Dhakaani Guul'dar (Bugbear)
entries: {@race Dhakaani Guul'dar (Bugbear)|ExploringEberron24|Dhakaani bugbears} are known as guul'dar, "strong folk," and are celebrated for their strength and courage. They help perform heavy labor where strength is required, but most yearn to prove their mettle on the battlefield, risking their lives to earn the glory known as atcha.

entries.name: Gnoll
entries: Fierce and feral, the first {@race gnoll|ExploringEberron24|gnolls} were hyenas infused with malefic power by archfiends of war and the wild. They were created as cruel soldiers to serve in the endless conflicts of fiends, but over the course of countless generations a number of gnoll clans broke their ties to their demon overlords. These free gnolls are fiercely loyal to their pack and their clan, and serve as a stabilizing force within Droaam.

Gnolls that are bound to the overlords are vicious and wild. Those who have escaped this bondage still have a fiendish spark within, but they contain and control this power. Some learn to wield it as Warlocks. Others known as hwyri train to fight demons and other supernatural threats. Even free gnolls can be aggressive, but they are gifted hunters and fiercely loyal to those they choose as family.

entries.name: Jhorgun'taal (Half-orc)
entries: Long ago, the orcs of the Shadow Marches welcomed human refugees from Sarlona. The two species have lived together in harmony for centuries. Most humans or orcs from the Marches have some degree of mixed lineage, even though they may use the game statistics of the species they outwardly resemble. However, the union of human and orc can produce children who have physical traits of both parent species. In the Shadow Marches, such people are called {@race Jhorgun'taal (Half-Orc)|ExploringEberron24|Jhorgun'taal}, "children of two bloods"; they are celebrated as a symbol of the bond between orcs and humans. Jhorgun'taal blend the endurance of their orc ancestors with the flexibility of humanity.

As House Tharashk has spread across Khorvaire, Jhorgun'taal are often found as inquisitives, bounty hunters, and prospectors. The Mark of Finding can manifest on humans, orcs, or Jhorgun'taal who can trace their ancestry to the Shadow Marches.

entries.name: Kalamer Landwalker (Merfolk)
entries: The Kalamer merfolk dwell in the Thunder Sea, and most spend their entire lives beneath the waves. However, a few are called to walk above the water. Those that embrace this path may become {@race Kalamer Landwalker (Merfolk)|ExploringEberron24|Kalamer Landwalkers}, gaining the magical ability to transform their fish-tail into a pair of humanoid legs. Landwalkers are exceptionally rare, and few surface-dwellers have ever seen one. Some Kalamer Landwalkers feel a call to accomplish a specific goal, fulfilling a mission for the good of the world. Others are driven purely by curiosity, and yearn to see new places and find wondrous things.

entries.name: Ruinbound
entries: The {@race Ruinbound|ExploringEberron24} are mutants that can be born to any humanoid species that has contact with the Daelkyr or their minions. A Ruinbound is born with a personal symbiont—an unnatural entity bound to the child. Unlike most symbionts, this entity cannot be separated from its host, and the two are permanently fused. Many Ruinbound have additional disturbing mutations; you can roll on the Ruinbound Mutations table for ideas, or create your own. These secondary mutations are disturbing, but they don't change the rules of how that character is played or grant mechanical benefits. For example, even if a Ruinbound seems to have no eyes, their vision uncannily works as well as any other member of their species, though it defies logic.

Aside from their mutations, Ruinbound share the appearance of their parent species. The Mror Holds have seen a surge of Ruinbound births since the War Below began, and there have always been Ruinbound orcs and humans in the Shadow Marches. Even in these places, however, the Ruinbound are rare and remarkable, and generally don't pass their traits on to their offspring. More information about the Ruinbound can be found in the Mror Holds section of {@book Uncharted Domains|ExploringEberron24|4}.

When making a Ruinbound character, work with your DM to determine the appearance of your Personal Symbiont. It is organic and clearly alien, and when you cast a cantrip with this trait, it should be obvious that the symbiont is the source. A symbiont that casts {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB} could be a thin tentacle or an ectoplasmic insect that emerges from your body and performs the action. An eyestalk protruding from your shoulder could grant you {@spell Guidance|XPHB} as it studies the situation and telepathically advises you—or it might blast your enemies with a {@spell Mind Sliver|XPHB}.

entries.name: Sahuagin
entries: The {@race sahuagin|ExploringEberron24} are an ancient species spawned in the ocean depths. With their armored skin and fearsome demeanor, they have long inspired terror in the people of the surface world. They are natural predators with aggressive instincts, kin to the shark and often devotees of the Devourer. But there is nothing innately evil about most sahuagin; in the depths of the Thunder Sea, sahuagin champions battle fiends and aberrations.

Sahuagin are amphibious humanoids with leathery skin, sharp teeth, and webbed hands and feet. They have finlike crests on their heads, which extend and retract in response to their mood. While the majority of sahuagin have gray-green scales, others have scales with dramatic, colorful patterns.

entries.name: Species Feats
entries: These feats reflect cultural traditions and unique capabilities tied to the species discussed in {@book Species of Eberron|ExploringEberron24|2}. Most of these feats are associated with a particular species, as summarized in the Species Feats table. For example, the {@area Changeling Metamorphosis|422|x} feat builds on a changeling's innate shape-shifting ability, so a human can't benefit from it. Some of these are General feats, which can be acquired at any point in a character's career. Others are Origin feats, reflecting specific cultural traditions or biological features of a species. As long as your DM approves, you can replace the normal Origin feat granted by your character's Background with an Origin feat associated with your species or backstory. So, if you're playing an Elf Cleric from Aerenal, you might take the {@background Acolyte|XPHB} background but replace the Magic Adept feat with Aereni Expertise.

entries: These feats are in the Origin Category.

entries.name: General Feats

entries.name: Spells
entries: Here are a few new spells you might find employed by a {@creature Magewright|ERLW}, other NPC, or player character in Khorvaire.

What is it?" Ban asked, carefully studying the ancient gauntlet. Pulling out her Duster, Dela passed the wand over the relic. Centuries of grime vanished, revealing blackened steel and glittering Khyber dragonshards. "The Hand of Halas Tarkanan. It's a weapon made to amplify the power of aberrant dragonmarks." She touched one of the embedded shards. "This gauntlet once leveled the towers of Sharn. And in the wrong hands, it could do so again."

Magic is an important part of everyday life in Eberron. Magic items aren't simply treasures or relics of a forgotten age; they're modern-day tools of industry and weapons of war. This section presents a range of magic items and other treasures, from the focus items of the dragonmarked houses to the living symbionts of the daelkyr. See the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG|6|Magic Items} for the rules on using magic items.

entries.name: Common Magic Items
entries: Magic is used in a multitude of minor ways that may have little impact on adventurers, but improve everyday life for common folk. {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE} and {@book Eberron: Rising from the Last War|ERLW} present a number of Common magic items, all of which can be found in Khorvaire. This section adds a number of additional items, but these are just the tip of the iceberg. Use these as a source of inspiration for what can be done, not as an absolute list of the only magic items found in Eberron.

Cantrips are a source of inspiration for Common magic items, though most only replicate a portion of a cantrip's effects. Consider {@item Clothes of Mending|XDMG}, which automatically mend themselves. The {@item Cleansing Stone|ERLW}, {@item Duster|ExploringEberron24}, and {@item Armor of Gleaming|XDMG} all employ the cleaning aspect of {@spell Prestidigitation|XPHB}, while the {@item Talking Wand|ExploringEberron24} provides the voice amplification effect of {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB}. Cleaning, heating, chilling, mending, creating illusory sounds or images—all are tools in the Cannith arsenal.

While most Common magic items have no impact on combat, a few items have practical value. The {@item Battle Rod|ExploringEberron24} and {@item War Staff|ExploringEberron24} increase the range of cantrips, while the {@item Armblade|ERLW} and {@item Integrated Tool|ExploringEberron24} provide minor benefits for warforged characters. As a DM, you can choose to combine a Common magic item's benefits with a more powerful magic item. For example, the extended range of a Common War Staff could be applied to a {@item Staff of Fire|XDMG}, or a warforged Armblade could wield a {@item Sun Blade|XDMG}.

entries.name: Dhakaani Magic Items
entries: Though the Empire of Dhakaan has no tradition of arcane artillery, the sages of the Kech Volaar are carefully studying the tools and techniques of the Five Nations, working to grasp the principles of the evoker and the conjurer. But while wands and Siege Staffs aren't yet part of the Dhakaani arsenal, their daashor artificers are exceptionally talented. The Dhakaani have mastered techniques of metallurgy and smithing that Cannith has yet to learn. They know techniques for refining and working adamantine alloys and other exotic metals, and for binding arcane energies into their creations. In ancient times, the empire produced many mighty artifacts. DMs will have to decide whether the present-day Dhakaani still have the ability to craft new artifacts, or if their greatest secrets were lost in the collapse of the empire.

This section describes a few unique Dhakaani relics that might be found across Khorvaire. Typically these are found in ancient tombs and ruins; such treasures as {@item Adamantine Armor|XDMG} are immune to the ravages of time. However, the Heirs of Dhakaan continue to craft fine weapons and armor, and Dhakaani champions are well equipped.

The daashor value function over fashion. Their tools and weapons are impeccably designed, but typically austere in form: blackened adamantine or steel, with emblems of clan and empire woven unobtrusively into the design. In addition to {@item Adamantine Weapon|XDMG|Adamantine Weapons}, Dhakaani may produce any sort of magical arms or armor. {@item Armor of Invulnerability|XDMG}, {@item Armor of Resistance|XDMG}, {@item Defender|XDMG|Defender weapons}, {@item Mace of Terror|XDMG}—any of these could be Dhakaani designs. While the Dhakaani use swords, bows, and spears, their champions often field flails, maces, and mauls. Other Dhakaani magic items are usually focused on battlefield use. For example, magical banners or instruments could inspire allies or instill fear in enemies.

The Heirs of Dhakaan seek to recover Dhakaani Artifacts and Legendary items, and they'll try to claim these most valuable items from other creatures through force or diplomacy. While it may disturb a warrior of Dhakaan to see a human wearing Dhakaani armor or carrying an adamantine blade from an imperial forge, they don't need to recover every relic of the past, and they may allow this to pass without incident.

entries.name: Dragonmark Focus Items
entries: Much of the influence of the dragonmarked houses is based on a simple principle: it's easier to amplify an existing magical effect, such as that of a dragonmark, than to create the same effect from nothing. Taken on their own, the powers granted by dragonmarks aren't overwhelmingly powerful. However, over the course of centuries, House Cannith and the Twelve have developed items that focus and enhance the powers of the mark to produce powerful, reliable effects. In many cases—such as the Storm Spires of House Lyrandar and the Creation Forges of House Cannith—the Arcane Congress has been unable to duplicate the effects of these powerful focus items for non-dragonmarked creatures. Other items have since been reproduced in forms that anyone can use, but an item that requires the user to possess a specific dragonmark is always easier to create and less expensive than one that produces the same effect for anyone, giving the dragonmarked houses an important advantage.

This chapter provides several new dragonmark focus items. In addition, you could have a dragonmark focus item that produces the same effect as an existing magic item from the Dungeon Master's Guide—except it can't be used or attuned unless you possess a particular dragonmark. House Lyrandar is working on a version of a {@item Broom of Flying|XDMG} for dragonmarked heirs, though they haven't perfected it yet. House Ghallanda is developing a {@i Portable Inn}—a version of the {@item Daern's Instant Fortress||Instant Fortress}—but it's proven difficult. It's always up to the DM to decide if there's a dragonmark focus item that replicates the effects of any given magic item, and if so, how readily it's available.

The Dragonmark Focus Items table provides examples of focus items, along with the item whose effects they reproduce and the mark required to use or attune to the focus item. A focus item's rarity is generally less than a similar item that anyone can use, reflecting the relative ease of manufacture. However, this doesn't mean they are readily available; dragonmark focus items are rarely sold in stores. They can only be created using proprietary tools, and are produced exclusively by House Cannith and the Twelve for use by trusted agents of the dragonmarked houses. So while many Medani inquisitives wear {@i Medi Spectacles}, they acquired them through service to the house, not by purchasing them with gold.

While a dragonmark focus item usually has the same general appearance as the item whose effects it duplicates, it bears the image of the required mark somewhere on the item, and often carries the sigil of the associated house. Siberys dragonshards are a vital component of focus items, most including a shard in some form. With that said, a focus item's design can differ from the usual magic item's form—the {@i Serpentine Mirror} has a similar effect to a {@item Crystal Ball|XDMG}, but it's a flat mirror as opposed to an orb.

entries.name: Miscellaneous Magic Items
entries: This section presents a few items that use magic readily accessible to the skilled artificers of Eberron. The Aereni Mask would generally only be crafted on the island of Aerenal, and only given to worthy Aereni elves. The rest might be purchased in the major cities of Khorvaire, though they might have limited quantities or require you to find an artifice willing to take a special commission.

entries.name: Symbionts
entries: The daelkyr create living tools and weapons, objects formed from chitin, bone, and muscle. Many of these items bond to their bearer, drawing sustenance from the creature attuned to them; for this reason, they are commonly called "symbionts." Though symbionts are living tools, they are mechanically considered a magic item, not a creature.

This section introduces eight new symbiont items, like those in {@book Eberron: Rising from the Last War|ERLW}. In addition, you could present any existing magic item as a daelkyr-made symbiont by describing the item as being made from organic materials. A {@item Dagger of Venom|XDMG} crafted by Valaara could be a chitin blade that's warm to the touch. A {@item Cloak of the Bat|XDMG} might feel like membranous leather, with veins running through the material. A {@item Periapt of Wound Closure|XDMG} could be a scarab that burrows into the flesh of the bearer, enhancing their blood. Even Common magic items can be symbionts; an {@item Everbright Lantern|ERLW} could be a sluglike creature with a luminescent body.

When presenting an existing item as a symbiont, the DM must decide whether to add the Symbiotic Nature feature that other symbionts have. When such an item is attuned, it can't be removed from the bearer, even if they desire it; the only way to end the {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} and remove a symbiont is to use an effect that ends a curse. This prevents the item from being taken away, but limits a character's free will, so it's up to the story you want to tell. While Symbiotic Nature is a common attribute for symbionts, it's not a requirement. A slug that functions as an Everbright Lantern wouldn't require Attunement. Even if the Periapt of Wound Closure is a scarab that digs into the flesh of the bearer, perhaps it could be pried loose, or it might release its grip voluntarily if the bearer ends the Attunement.

entries.name: Siberys Dragonmarks
entries: The thirteen true dragonmarks are manifestations of the Draconic Prophecy. From the inception of Eberron, the idea has been that when a dragonmark first appears, it is quite small, but that over time the mark and the powers it grants can grow—potentially becoming a Lesser or Greater dragonmark. In addition, there has always been the concept of Siberys Dragonmarks: massive dragonmarks that can appear unexpectedly and which grant exceptional power.

{@book Eberron: Forge of the Artificer|EFA} presents dragonmarks as feats: A {@filter base feat that grants the dragonmark|feats|source=|category=d}, and a {@filter Greater Mark|feats|source=efa|search=Greater} feat that enhances it. Forge of the Artificer also includes an Epic Boon feat called {@feat Boon of Siberys|EFA}, which grants the use of a single spell. While the Boon of Siberys could be used to represent a Siberys Dragonmark, this book presents another approach. The Siberys Dragonmarks that follow are Supernatural Gifts, as described in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG|2}. Such a mark is something to be granted at the DM's discretion, when circumstances unlock power within a character that they never knew they possessed. Traditionally, these marks only manifest on people who have a blood tie to a dragonmarked house, although this connection could be distant and unknown to the person who develops the mark. Siberys Dragonmarks can appear on someone who already has the dragonmark in question, but the basic Dragonmark feat is not required. Likewise, a character can choose to take the Boon of Siberys regardless of whether or not they have one of these Siberys Dragonmarks. While a Siberys Dragonmark is something granted by the DM, they are more powerful that the example Supernatural Gifts presented in the Dungeon Master's Guide and should not be bestowed lightly or at low levels. A character cannot possess more than one Siberys Dragonmark, and they cannot have a Siberys Dragonmark while also having a Dragonmark feat associated with a different dragonmark.

entries.name: Ramifications of a Siberys Mark
entries: Usually a mark appears when the character engages in a heroic action somehow related to the gifts of the mark—but ultimately, a Siberys Dragonmark is a manifestation of the Prophecy, and its appearance is a signal that the bearer has a destiny to fulfil. Regardless of whether they manifest on a dragonmarked heir or an unknown foundling, the dragonmarked houses value heirs with Siberys Dragonmarks. A character who displays such a mark is treated with more respect by other members of the house, but the barons and seneschals may also place greater demands on them. So, a Siberys Dragonmark is a blessing, but it can also be a burden.

For guidance on how to use a creature's stat block, consult the introduction of the {@book Monster Manual|XMM}.
